metadata.title: Plotting in Pandas Just Got Prettier | by Rebecca Vickery | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Plotting in Pandas Just Got Prettier
metadata.description: The plotting functionality in the popular Python data analysis library Pandas has always been one of my go-to methods for super quick charts. However, the available visualisations have always been…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: I send out a monthly newsletter if you would like to join please sign up via this link. Looking forward to being part of your learning journey!

all_paragraphs: The plotting functionality in the popular Python data analysis library Pandas has always been one of my go-to methods for super quick charts. However, the available visualisations have always been fairly basic and not particularly pretty.

I have often found myself performing some visual data exploration quickly using the Pandas plotting functionality. But then redoing the visualisation using one of the ‘prettier’ plotting libraries like Plotly or Bokeh when it came to presenting the insights to a stakeholder.

Since the latest Pandas release, 0.25.3, this is no longer necessary and you can now use third-party visualisation libraries as backends to the Pandas plotting functionality. Plotly, the popular Python library for interactive web-based visualisations, also very recently released a Pandas plotting backend.
Let’s take a look at how we can create richer visualisations using the Plotly and Bokeh backends.
To activate different backends for the plotting functionality, after importing pandas, add this line of code.

Plotly is a Python library that supports a wide range of rich interactive visualisations. One of the benefits of the Plotly package is that it is built on top of the Javascript version of the library which means that the charts are web-based and can be displayed as HTML files or embedded in Python-based web applications. You can also download the visualizations as high-quality image files so are ideal for use in documents or papers.
Let’s walk through some quick examples of usage as a backend for the Pandas plotting functionality.

You will need to install Plotly if you don’t already have it pip intsall plotly. If you are using Plotly in Jupyterlab you will need to perform a couple of extra installation steps to display the visualisations. First, install IPywidgets.
Then run this to install the Plotly extension.

To illustrate the usage of the plotting backends I will be using a data set taken from openml.org called the ‘wine’ dataset. It can be found here, but can also be directly imported into a notebook using the following code (you will need Scikit-learn installed first).
The wine data set consists of a number of features of wine types and the corresponding label. The first few rows of the data set are shown below.
Let’s use the Plotly back end to explore the data set a little.

The plotting functionality works in much the same way as the standard Pandas plotting functions only now the visualisations are displayed with the richness of Plotly. The code below plots the relationship between the two features in the data set.
If we hover over the chart we can see that we have options to download the chart as a high-quality image file.
We can combine the Pandas groupby function and create a bar chart to summarise the difference in mean Hue between the classes.
Let’s add class to the scatter chart we created earlier. Plotly allows you to easily apply different colours to each class so that we can visualise the separation.

Bokeh is another Python plotting library that provides rich and interactive visualisations. The visualisations can be viewed in a web browser, embedded in web applications or be used to create interactive dashboards. Bokeh even has a streaming API so it is possible to create realtime visualisations for streaming data such as financial markets.
Full documentation for pandas-bokeh can be found here. The library can be pip installed pip install pandas-bokeh .
To display Bokeh visualisations in Jupyterlab we need to install two new extensions.
Let’s recreate the scatter chart we created earlier using the Bokeh backend.
The visualisation is shown below. Bokeh charts are automatically interactive.
Bokeh has a plot_grid function that can create dashboard-like layouts for multiple charts. The code below creates four charts in a grid layout — shown below the code.

The addition of multiple third party back ends to the built-in Pandas plotting functionality has substantially increased the power of this library for data visualisation. This article has given only a flavour of the functionality now available through the Plotly and Bokeh backends. If you take a closer look at the documentation you will see that there is a lot more available to create rich dashboards and web applications using this new functionality.
